context: After Washington had returned to Williamsburg, Dinwiddie ordered him to lead a larger force to assist Trent in his work. <b3_0><b4_0>While en route<b4_0/><b3_0/>, Washington learned of Trent's retreat. Since Tanaghrisson <a2_2>had promised<a2_2/> support to the British, Washington continued toward Fort Duquesne and met with the Mingo leader. Learning of a French scouting party in the area, Washington, <a0_0>with Tanaghrisson and his party, <a0_2><a0_4><b5_0>surprised the Canadians on May 28<a0_4/><a0_2/> in what became known as the <a0_3>Battle of Jumonville Glen<b5_0/><a0_3/><a0_0/>. They <a0_1><a1_0>killed <a1_1><a1_3><b6_0>many of the <a1_2>Canadians<a0_1/>, including their commanding officer<a1_2/>, Joseph Coulon de Jumonville<b6_0/><a1_3/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, whose head was reportedly split open by Tanaghrisson with a tomahawk. The historian Fred Anderson suggests that Tanaghrisson was acting <a2_4><b7_0>to <a2_1>gain the support of the British and <a2_0><a2_3>regain authority over his own people<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_1/>. They had been inclined to support the French, with whom they had long trading relationships<a2_0/>. One of Tanaghrisson's men told Contrecoeur that Jumonville had been killed by British musket fire.
